text: Flasa z Prahy. Zlta farba, bez peny. Vona jemne sladka, plna jablk roznych farieb. Chut plna jablkova, jemne ostra na jazyku. Dochut trpka, trosku kyselkava a kvasnicova. Vyssia nasytenost. Vyborne pitelne, osviezujuce.

Bought at the domain. A luxury cuvée in which Dupont aims to emulate the vinous character of a champaign while using apples as fermentable sugars base. It makes for a subtle aroma, with chalky, dusty, bone-like apples with no residual sugars left and surprising minerality. Extremely dry, but not so acidic flavor profile, chalky, mineral, woodsy, finely bubbled. It is a refreshing bottle which serves a purpose on the table as a friend to lobster among other things, but not something I would frequently want to drink on its own. Fairly refined, but not very complex nor apple-forward. An interesting creation, but not as charming to me as many of the other Dupont experiments.

side by side tasting of Cuvée Colette with the Triple. Both more refermented and drier than all other available ciders.

In general, the longer fermentation makes both the CC and Triple drier and less sweet than the "regular" versions. Nonetheless still outstanding. Cuvée Colette really has a champagne touch to it, very dry "zéro dosé" dry, soft dry sherry notes, pinot meunier alike. The triple plays on the bitterness and tannins (and "non-dégorgé"). Cuvée Colette: 3.9, Triple: 3.7

A golden cider with aroma of tart complex apple, light Brett, light lactic notes, very nice. In mouth, a nice tart apples, dry and puckering, light Brett and grapeskin, very nice. Bottle at Cajun Café spring beer fest 2016.
Bottle at Salon piva. Golden yellow color. Aroma of green apples, wood, fruit, light caramel, some spices. Taste is complexed, higher carbonation, light caramel, taste of champagne, dry finish

Vintage 2011.
Golden yellow colour.
Nose: Lovely perfumed and vinous nose, rich and rather deep yellow and red apple notes.
Palate: Dry but with a sweet fruit note. Together with the maturity of the fruit this rounds the wine off and gives it an almost off-dry mouthfeel. Nice and rounded acidity balances the whole thing out. Quite rich mouthfeel. Rich mousse/carbonation. 
Mature and drinking very well now but seems to have enough fruit and acidity to last and potentially develop for another 2-4 years.

Sweet green apple aroma and flavor with a little funk throughout - really dug this one as well. Maybe even hints of woodiness, grass, and vanilla in there, and a touch more bitter than most ciders. Well done.

750mL bottle purchased at The Davis Beer Shoppe. Aroma has a fairly significant mineral character present. Light apple character is present along with a bit of a dusty champagne-like yeast nose. Quite dry. Pale, transparent yellow body with a large, fizzy white head present. Quickly dissipates. Starts quite carbonated and spritzy. Becomes a bit metallic and full of minerals (sulfur) in the middle. Has a very dry, somewhat astringent flavoring towards the end. Apple flavor is very minimal. Just lots of basement and cobwebs in this.

750ml bottle, 2009. Yellow golden colour, short-lived white bubbly head and aroma of juicy apple with light oak & funk. Taste is sweetish, fruity apple, green apple, grapes, tart & dry, with notes of wood, oak, barnyard and light tannins. Crisp mouthfeel, light to medium bodied, spritzy carbonation, drying tangy lightly tannic finish. Very drinkable.

Light lemon in colour quite heavily sparkling in the glass, Pours like champagne - big fizz disappearing instantly. A little sweet with honey on the nose. Quite rich, honey and a nice fizz in the mouth. A touch sharp on the finish and overall quite dry.

Bottle from the cidery. Pours clear straw colour with champagne like fizz. Sour apple aroma. The taste is quite sweet with sour apple and a touch of aniseed. High levels of carbonation giving a full mouthfeel. Very pleasant.

750ml bottle (Stockholm, Riga)
Aroma quite restrained, just a slight appley hint, but more a woody wineyness. Pale and effervescent. Crisp on the tongue. Initially quite sharp, but as it warms a bit, some sweetness comes through. Nice lip-smacking sourness. Good crisp cidre to have with grilled meat. A champagne of ciders.

750ml bottle (thanks FatPhil). Clear golden color. No head, non expected. Leather, sweetish, cow manure in aroma. Leather, fruity, apples, acidic in taste. Crisp and dry mouthfeel. Fruity caramel in aftertaste.

Bottled. Golden colour with no head. Aroma is apples (green and ripe ones), and mild sweetness. Flavour is earthy, mild sweetish sour apples as well as some yeasty and farmyardy funk to it. Somewhat dry palate.

Pours a clear golden color with a decent white head. Aroma is sour, green apple, fuji sweet apple, vinegar. Taste is clean apple juice, slight vinegar bite, weak cinnamon, sweet yet dry at the finish. Palate and drinkability are amazingly smooth. Definitely worth a try.
Champagne bottle at YNWA Beershop. No head. Hazy light green body. Wineous bittersweet aroma and flavor with a high carbonation and a nice acidity. Long dry finish.

750ml bottle from TheCheeseMan, thanks Dan. Clear pale yellow in colour with no head but lots of visible carbonation. The aroma is fantastic, wood, vanilla, apples, brown sugar with just a hint of alcohol. The flavour follows what the aroma brought, its like an iced cider without all the alcohol and not still. Finishes quite long and bubbly. The best regular cider that I have had, nearing ice cider in terms of flavour and aroma. Fantastic stuff right from the start.

Bottle. Pours a clear light yellow body with loads of visible bubbles. Nose is apple cores, yellow apple peel, wood, sawdust and hints of cellar mold and raisins. Taste is yellow apples, sawdust, wood, sweet apple cores, mellow cellar mold tones, raisins and hints of straw. Light body, semi-dry finish and high carbonation. A mellow and smooth cider, obviously aged with a rather high degree of success. Nice one.
Bottle from Binnys in Lincoln Park. Very crisp and effervescent. Dry, but lacking in depth. Mild red apple and faint skin.

A 0.75l corked bottle from 2009. A massive white fizzing head that vaporizes as quickly as Ive never seen before. Like a champagne in many ways really. The cider is as no big shock to the system, clear and pale in color. Lots of aroma! I get green apples, a ton of cellar, lots or cork, wood and rhubarb. Really nice! A really high carbonation level on this and it has a good apple flavor all the way. That massive carbonation level gives it a push. Some cellar with wet rocks and a soft dry tongue in the aftertaste. Its really good this! 09.08.2013

Refrigerated 75 cl green bottle corked, capped, and foiled poured into a white wine glass. Pours very pale yellow with small white head which dissapates very quickly, medium carbonation, aroma is beautiful tart apple, and no lacing. Taste is nice apple. Something in the finish is not that great, not worth the price.
Pale gold color with a big puffy white head. Apples, dust, old basement flavors, leather, barnyard, manure, yeast. Fuck I love ciders like this. Awesome.

750 ml "champagne" bottle, vintage 2009, from Vinmonopolet. ABV is 6.9%. Very pale straw coloured. Pours very fizzy with a large white head that dies out instantly. Interesting aroma of cider apples, wild yeast / farmhouse, leather and funk. Dry and crisp flavour, cider apples of course, but also notes of dry champagne. Not as "coarse" and sulphurous as many other ciders. Very pleasant to drink, and refreshing on this warm summer evening.

750 ml champagne bottle. A pale golden body with a light, foamy white head. Lively carbonation like sparkling wine. Mild aroma of apples, yeast and slightly acidic fruit. Flavor is a bit like champagne with strong apple notes and yeast. Fine, light body, tickling carbonation and apples in aftertaste, somehow both sweet and dry. Not the most typical cider, reminds me a lot of champagne, still a clear apple flavor. Very enjoyable.

Beautiful bottle, extra half point for appearance. Pours crystal clear pale straw colored with a massive champagne head that settles to aggressive effervescence. Aroma of bright fruit with a dusty edge. Taste starts sweet with peaches and apricots in the background, then tart and dry earthy  apples. Delicious and easy to drink.
75cl bottle from caves legrand filles et fils in Paris. Clear golden color with no head. Fizzy carbonation. Medium sweetness, bitterness and sourness. Very very balanced.

750mL Bottle. Thanks for sharing, Amy! 2006. Wow, wow, wow. This is some stunning stuff. The champagne presentation gives this a special feel. The aroma crackles with fresh apples and reduced apple syrup, prickled with wild fruit touches. The flavor and body come in movements, which I always think is a hallmark of a really well crafted beverage. It starts out sweet and bright, bringing the fresh apples out, but then takes on a sudden tartness that really grabs the tongue, finishing with a clean bitter bite to sweep the tongue clean. Apple flavors roam around in earth, plum, brandy, chalk, and raspberry stem. All around fantastic.
Bottle. Golden-yellow colour with some white bubbles. Aroma is apple, yeast, sugar, cellar notes. Flavour is dry, apple, yeast, cellar notes, sourness, sugar. Nice cider

Short wine glass pour during Jimmy 43s $10 Tuesday Tasting, NYC Cider Week Edition.

Champagne. Pale, clear gold body.

Slight, slight funk on the nose. Red dessert apples, green grapes, earthy yeast.

Taste is sweet & tart apples. Bruised pears. Citrus rind. A bit musky. Tangy & yeasty. Touch of saline. 

Tight champagne carbonation. More acidic then tart. Dry, satisfying woody finish.

This stuff is helping me kick my terrible mimosa habit, one remortgage at a time. :)
user_location: FT: Stale Polotmavý in Queens, New York, USA

text:
Bottle. Head is initially small, fizzy, white, fully diminishing. Body is sparkling light yellow. Aroma is notes of apples and apple skins, flowers, oak, cinnamon, barnyard/horseblanket, band-aid, and cinderblock/minerals. Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly to moderately acidic. Finish is lightly sweet, lightly to moderately acidic. Medium body, watery/foamy texture, lively/fizzy carbonation.

A delightful, elegant example.  This still has the wild horse-and-barn character Dupont is known for, but its more in the background here and integrates nicely with more delicate floral scents.  I wish the aroma was a little more vibrant, but whats there is very nice.  More enjoyable in the mouth, with its Champagne-like bubbles and excellent sweet/sour balance.  A very enjoyable cider, but I wouldnt buy it again due to the steep price ($30 here).
Bottle. Pours a clear pale yellow color with a small fast disappearing white head. Hasa  fruity spicy apple aroma. Fruity slightly spicy tart apple flavor. Has a fruity spicy apple finish.

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ Pours golden with a fast dissipating white head. Aroma of apples, some chalk, fruitiness and yeast. Flavor is rustic sweet apples with some sweet and fruity apple peel. Medium boyd average carbonation.

Bottle, 75cl corked. A clear, lighlty sparkling yellowish golden cider. Lighlty cellarish nose with lots of pleasant apple scents. Some orchard notes. Its full-bodied, dry and maybe a bit effervescent, but really pleasant on the palate. Delicious flavor with apples and orchard and a faint cellerish note. Semi-sweet, with a tart touch. Overall, certainly a tasteful cider. 120623

Bottle 750ml @ fonefan
Pours clear pale yellow with a fast diminishing white head. Aroma has notes of sour apples. Taste is light to medium sweet with a dry finish. Body is medium, texture is thin to oily, carbonation is soft to fizzy
Bottle, 6.9%. Clear pale yellow with small diminishing white head. Aroma is apples, fruit and tart. Flavour is apples, fruit, dry, little sweet ,wood, little vanilla and a little tart.
Bottle. Small head with short duration. Color is pale golden. Aroma and taste are rich tart apples, sulphur and stable. Semi dry. Great stuff.

750ml Bottle (at 6.9%ABV per the Bottle).:  Aroma of apple, Brett, acetic acid, and wood.  Poured light gold in color with a small, fizzy, very loose, white head that disappeared immediately.  Clear.  Very sparkling.  Flavor is heavily sweet.  Tastes of apples, acetic acid, and wood.  Light to medium body.  Tingly, then dry texture.  Lively carbonation.  Heavily sweet, apple, light acetic acid, barrel finish is lightly dry.

Bottle, 2006 vintage - Golden honey amber with a thin ring of white bubbly head. Musty, gentle apples on the nose, sweet and a bit overripe. A touch of plastic that isnt overbearing, as a nice tartness comes through. Taste is pretty dry and tart, with white grape, lightly bitter apples, and a nice mellow vanilla/oak note. Pretty well carbonated and nice firm body with a touch of syrupyness. Wow...this is fantastic.

750mL 6.9% at Paradiso Dupont. Poured a clear light gold with no head fizz really and heavy sparkling carbonation. Nose is semi wild...hints of Brett biproducts but not really wild yeast per se. More hints of acetone than must/hay. Pretty sharp/stinging nose. Taste has a pretty heavy plastic/phenol character right off the bat with huge effervescence hiding complexities. Lots of champagne character in taste and mouthfeel. Not sure Im digging the huge phenol/plastic character. Pretty disappointing. Overall sparking, dry, vinous for cider.

Bottle from the 2006 batch.  Pours a clear gold with a light orange tinge, a small white head while pouring but it goes away immediately.  Big and sweet, some ice cider notes, with that big thick sweetness, a touch of wood.  Medium bodied, a bit more wood comes through, a slight alcohol note, warm musky yeast shows up as well.  Very nice.  Finishes fairly dry, with more lingering barrel notes and spicy apple.  Very nice.

Otown Throwdown III> 04 bottle  Pours a light apple juice color- good rolling carbonation.  Aroma is nice caramelized apple with some green skin slight acetaldehyde, light aple acidity smells slightly subdued- light oxidation, a lighter refined airy version of niege in the smell, .  Flavor is apple juice, pulp, acid, light toast, vanilla, honey, earthy apple core, malic acid with a slight leathery yeasty dirty finish- almost bready like some champagne can get- nice lively carbonation to the end keeps the palate nice- dry, lightly tart and slight astringent skins.  Nice!

c.lear yellow, small white head2 very dry slightly alcoholic aroma. Only very faint apple aroma5. Flavor is very dry, dry as champaigne, also tastes .ike champaigne, but with an apple note.also faint salty

2004 Vintage 750ml (6.9%). Pours with a large white head that diminishes to a ring over a mostly clear golden body.  Highly effervescent looking. Aroma is slightly tart, light phenolics, horse, sweet dough, bright and lightly acidic. A bit of soil, sulfur and brown sugar. Taste is rich, acidic, sweet-tart balance, caramel, light oxidation, musty, raisins. Really actually hard to describe, but it feels, rich, complex, and balanced, but my words fail me on true descriptors.  A bit boozy, phenolic, rich, lively bubbles, good and interesting.
citrus, floral, grape,golden, hazy, white foam, medium sweetness, lightly bitter, light body, thin feel, lively,

Appearance: Pours a clear, still, light yellow-hued body.

Smell: Vibrant scent of juiced apples with a light sweetish quality to it and a minute, background farmhouse mustiness.

Taste: Starts tart and lightly musty with the moderate degree of sweetness coming up a half second behind. Apples. Faint touch of bitter tannins. Apples. A little carbonic bite as theres a fast flash of carbonation at the end. Finishes dry.

Mouthfeel: Medium-light body. Modestly carbonated.

Drinkability: Very pleasant drink on a Springtime evening. Reminds me of Asti Spumante if you let a good portion of the carbonation die out.

2004 Vintage Bottle.  Pours crystal clear apple-juice colored, lively stream of bubbles rising solely in the center of the glass, causing a gaseous circle of bubbling in the center of the very thin, almost non-existent  head.  Nose is full of wood and apples, very earthy, some cedar and oak, some must, some cork, a touch of vanilla..but really, the wood accents are quite nice...like a wino in an orchard, the nose is comforting.  Fizziness greets the tongue, followed by bandagey wet wood accented apples, superb vinous qualities, a nice fermentation/solvent accent to the apple flavors..pretty funky, really.  I was hoping itd be funky...and it is...not really in the barnyard realm of things, but more bandage-like and vinous..in a great, relaxing way.  The alcohol and wood makes it nicely full bodied.  Pricey bottle, but still...super good.
graprfruit, apple,vinegar light, yellow,heavy cloying sweetness, lightly bitter, medium sourness, medium body, lively,
2006 Vintage. Golden with a white head. Aroma of apples and fruit. Sweet apple flavour with fruit and a little bitterness. Very bland.

Bottle, bought @ Vinens Verden, Odense.
Pours a super-nice clear golden. Fizzy thin head disappears as I pour it. Two small streams of bubbles surge upwards. Aroma has lots of green apple, oak and dryness. Highish carbonation, fine frothy mouthfeel. Flavour is relatively dry, some sweet green apples and a slightly more tart note of red apples. Fresh and nice.
Bottled. A light golden beer with a thin off-white head. The aroma is sweet with strong notes of apples. The flavor is sweet with notes of apples, leading to a lightly tart finish.

750mL bottle, dated 2004.  Clear golden with a two finger white head, low retention.  Aroma of sweet apple juice and honey.  Flavor is a little bit tart with a semi-dry finish, minimal bitterness.  Medium body, moderate fizzy carbonation.  Pretty good cider--not crazy complex, but good-- though $25 a bottle is a little steep.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: 2006 bottle. Golden with no head. Fresh apple aroma with notes of brett and wood. Dry and slightly tart apple peel flavour. Tasty and refreshing.

UPDATED: JAN 4, 2015 2006 vintage @VinensVerden, Odense.  75cl Bottle. Thanks to MadsNP.  Pours clear yellow with a fading bubbly head leaving small and handsome curtains. Nose and taste  is of sweet and sour apples, hay, wood, dust and barnyard. Very fresh with a nice dry end. Re-rate 2015. Crisp, dry, red apples and wood. Well balanced and sooo tasty! 3,8-4.1
Pours yellow with some fluffy bubbles.  Smells appley and sweet.  Tastes funky and tarte with some spicy hints on the finish.

On tap at Novare Res in portland. Pours with a huge white foamy head that is gone after you blink.  This tastes out of this world good, aroma of old apples.  Flavor is like a nice fresh cider with a little funk thrown in.  It may be my first real cider, but I cant wait to try more.

Corked bottle, vintage 2004, 4 years oldHazy blond color. Elegant aroma: apples, wood, sweet nuts, light sourness. Quite dry mouthfeel, with some apples, citrus fruits, fresh wood, all well mixed together; quite sour; good carbonation. Very good.

2006 - Clear golden body, lots of sparkle, huge white head, that disappears very fast; Very clear a little simple apple aromas, a very little dust and aroma of old barrel behind; Huge sparkle in quite fruity acid body, a little tannin, simple, lacks complexity; Long finish lots of dust aroma, again a little rotten barrel, thin sharp apple aromas as well. Alright, very special but not amazing in any way.
Bottle. Not that sweet hence definately not to my liking. Maybe I am not experienced enough, but the aroma and taste of apples are far away...
Clear golden with tiny off white head. Sweet aroma with glue and apple notes. Atificial apples notes in the very sweet flavor.
Pale golden colour with a white head. Perry fruity aroma with sweet notes. Peery fruity and sweet flavor.

UPDATED: DEC 17, 2009 Bottle @ Amerikaner blindsmagning @ Papsoe, Bottle #29.]Clear light to medium yellow color with virtually none head. Aroma is moderate apple, wood. Flavor is moderate sweet with a long duration, and a dry finish. Body is medium, texture is watery, carbonation is flat. (190608) 7-2-7-3-13 
Bottle 750ml.@ DØE Tasting, Fox & Hounds, Holstebro. [ Vintage 2006 ].Clear light to medium yellow color with a average, frothy, good lacing, fully diminishing, white head. Aroma is moderate apple, wood, barnyard. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and moderate acidic with a average to long duration, a dry finish. Body is medium, texture is watery, carbonation is flat. [20091027]  8-3-8-3-16

Pours with a nice, fizzy, almost champagne level of carbonation.  The head is a pale, just off-white color and the cider is a nice, brilliantly clear gold color.  The carbonation makes an expressive, aromatic, apple note quite noticeable as I am pouring this cider.  This smells of fresh, aromatic apples that are backed by a bit of flinty yeast and a touch of alcohol towards the end.

Fairly sweet tasting, though not sticky in any way and there seems to be a touch of butter to the finish (seems to be a bit of diacetyl, though it can be hard to pick out at times from underneath all of the fruit notes).  The carbonation provides a nice, almost peppery note and there is perhaps a touch of spicy notes that also help to balance the up front sweetness.  Lightly tart tasting throughout the flavor profile, which also helps to provide some balance.  This is quite aromatic in its apple flavors / character, almost floral in a sweet nectar sort of manner.  Definitely very apple like, though not in a simplistic Red Delicious way, instead it has a complex, aromatic apple character that is quite refreshing and quite tasty.  This has a substantial level of tannin to it as well, which really helps with not only the texture, but also the complexity and balance of this brew.

This is definitely a great example of a cider that captures the apple character quite well.  I’ll admit to preferring the funkier and drier examples, but this one is certainly no slouch and is very enjoyable.  Even the diacetyl note that is softly in the finish of the flavor is not able to detract very much here.

Richmond Summer Gathering. C&C 750, 2004 vintage. Lightly hazed gold with tons of carbonation. Funky nose, green apple and some barnyardy notes. Sweet apple, light and easy to drink, crisp. Yeasty flavors, some tartness creeps in. Crisp, dry finish, akin to a gueze. Side note: lots of funky mold on the cork. I thought this was a BIG winner, my second fave of the tasting. Well done!

04 @ Richmond/Williamsburg Gathering-750ml Bottle-pours a disappearing white head and straw color with effervescence.  Aroma is apple, grain, towards a Gueze.  Taste is champagne, sweet, bready, tart, apple, grain, towards a Gueze, some grassy, slight musty/funky.  Good effervescence.  Occasional.  Thanks Immy for sharing.

(Bottle 75 cl) Courtesy of Storm. Clear golden with a lively fizzy head that dissipates fast. Fresh and clean apple aroma. Medium body with lightly swet apple notes - very clean apple - and a high carbonation. Rather dry finish. Very clean and drinkable. 190608

Bottle courtesy of Immy at the Williamsburg Gathering. 750mL corked and caged. Hazy golden pour. Lots of bubble strands throughout the body and a short fizzy white head, Nose is candy apple, apple skins, green apple and some yeasty/funky notes. Some wet wood begins to come through as well. Taste is sweet apple, some soft candyish notes, more green apple and apple skins along with funky yeast flavors. It was mentioned that this tasted like "cheap champagne" at one point, though I disagree with that synopsis. Body was very light and fizzy. Crisp at times and dry. Ended with more sweet apple, green apple, soft spice and more funky yeast. Nice!

2004 bottle shared by Immy at the 2008 Richmond Summer Gathering in Williamsburg. Pours a yellowish gold color with a medium head. Slightly funky green apple aroma. Sour apple taste, very dried. Full bodied with strong effervescence. Very nice.

750ml bottle, 2004 vintage. Thanks to Immy at Richmond Summer Gathering @ Williamsburg. Pours hazy golden in color with white head. Aroma sweet and apples. Taste of apples, yeasty and champagne with dry finish.
Yellow-golden with a small head. The aroma has a light sweetness, notes of overripe apple, wood and damp forest soil. The same notes are found in the flavour, and it’s a quite charming cider.

Gold with a thin white head.  Aroma is granny smith apples, pink lady apples, light tartness with some sweetness.  Taste is light alcohol, light tartness, very light sweetness.  A little too fizzy for my liking but ok.

Botte #29 at Papsoes blindtasting.
Clear yellow coloured with a medium sized white head.
Aroma of pears and apples with fruity notes
Flavour of fruits, pears and apples with acidic notes.

Bottle. Papsoes MadsBerg homecoming blindtasting, bottle #29. Pours clear and golden yellow with a lacing white head. Dry apple and mild artificial paint/chemical aroma. Flavour is dry and mild woody apple. Dry citric and apple flavour towards the finish. Ends dry fruity and light artificial.

Bottle. Clear yellow-golden with a greenish touch, very lively with no head. Looks like a mature champagne. Aromas of forest floor, a little ashy, sweet apples and honey. The flavor is balanced but a little thin, lacks in complexity due to the high expectations the aromas gave me. Fresh and clean.
a colour like a chardoney, sparkling palate with a nose dominated of apples, gazolin and hay, treefallen fruit. Sparkling and dry fruity feeling

Bottle. [After party @ Papsoe, thanks buddy] Pale yellow color. Aroma of fresh apple, mild citrus, light dusty feel, somewhat mild yeasty notes as well. Medium bodied with an average carbonation and dry texture. Moderated sour flavor with light sweet notes. Dry sour fresh apple finish.

Wow.  A $25 bonus from pepsican (among many others).  Thanks Andy!  Cork pops hard, like champagne, but no overflow.  Pour yellow with higher carbonation.  Chardonnay or champagne like in flavor as well, but not quite so dry. Good, great with a goat cheese.  Not as sweet (as thus not as good for someone with a sweet tooth like me) as an ice cider.  Very good. 3.8-3.9.
Bottle. Not that sweet hence definately not to my liking. Maybe I am not experienced enough, but the aroma and taste of apples are far away...

75 cl bottle. Shared with TanjaT. Clear yellow colour with a very fizzy head, but fast disappearing. Nice aroma of apple, and with hints of yeast. Very little sweet with notes of apples, very tasty and with a dry and refreshing aftertaste. Nearly just as good as a good champagne.

Bottle from Beerlando and another from a forgotten store in NJ - Golden color with a nice amount of bubbly effervescence.  Aroma dominated by thick, tart/sweet apples. some wood and a bit of naturey funk.  Flavor has a wonderful mix of tart/sour/sweet/crisp/juicy/fresh apples with some wood and sugar.  Wonderful - great mouthfeel and a wonderful swee/tart finish.  Absolutely great how a wonderful apple varietal mix comes together and produces a knockout - much like those fine Bordeaux wine blends.  Absolutely a treat - I must buy more of this genius cider.

2004 750ml bottle from tytoanderso and I got another from pepsican; dont remember which is which?; Nose of tartness, apples, and a lightly funky note; translucent yellow with a small yellowish head; flavor is fairly much on the tart side, with the aplle coming through strong and a background sweetness; finish is light sour funkiness.

25 oz bottle, shared by kmweaver.  Pours a clear pale yellow with a small fizzy white head.  Minimal to no visible carbonation.  Nice fresh clean apple nose with a bit of funkiness.  The flavor is fresh pressed juice, nicely balaned between the sweet and tart notes, leaning towards the sweet side.  A little dry funkiness on the finish.  Mouthfeel is medium bodied with moderate fizzy carbonation.  Nice lingering fruity finish.  Overall, very nice for my limited experience with cider.

Courtesy of kmweaver. Clear apple body with a tiny white head, fading. The nose is sweet apple juice with a bit of honey. The flavor is moderately sweet, moderately tart with lots of fresh apple juice, some honey and cotton candy. Medium  body is soft with moderate carbonation.

Bottle shared by kmweaver.  Clear yellow appearance.  Nice spicy green apple skin nose, lightly peppery.  Prickly and bubbly, effevescent, bright, light on the palate, with some spritzy apple and light white grape flavors.  Quite good.
Thanks to Ken for this one.  Clear yellow with a steady amount of visible effervescence rising.  Aroma is a slightly sour tangy apple.  Flavor is a delicate tangy fruity apple.

750mL bottle.  Pours a clear, oily medium golden-yellow color; basically headless.  Tons of fresh apple cider and funk in the aroma; just gorgeous, funky fresh apple presence.  Medium-to-full mouthfeel: loads of fresh apples, funk, sugar and generous apple cider; unlike ice ciders, this has just tons of dry, fresh apple presence; fresh-pressed apples and cobwebby funk.  Great, funky-dry cider; intensely drinkable.  Medium finish, showing sugar, apple cider, and just a touch of honey.
Sparkling yellow color with faint head.  Spicy apple and calvados on the aroma.  Tart apple flavor with a smooth dry finish.

Boboski hooks it up again.  Ciders are something I have truly come to adore and actively seek out, and this one is up there as one of my all time favorites.  The cider pours a perfectly crystalline color, with a fine bead of bubbles wafting upwards vigorously.  The aroma is beguiling, complex and almost otherworldly.  The fusion of Earth and orchard are evident.  Hints of wood, vanilla, acidic apples, floral notes, hints of citrus zests and a touch of alcohol to balance everything nicely.  The flavor is an epiphany, With a dry apple note to start everything off in the right direction, with the wood balancing the mid-notes, the close is a delicate and graceful acidity, pulling everything together.  Absolute a stunning creation and worthy of further praise.

Sampled at joebrews weekly beer tasting at Cellars Wine & Spirits in ST Paul, MN. Pours a clear light golden cider beverage with a fast dissolving white head that dissipates clean. Aroma of tart apples, a touch of yeast funk, some lime zest and a touch of honey. Taste is thin spritzy, light tart apples some light barnyard funk and lemon zest. Finish is slightly dry and mild tart with the remaining lemon zest flavor.

(bottle, thanks Joebrew) Pours light gold with a white head that dissipates.  Looks like champagne.  Smell of tart apple, light funk, and lemon.  Taste was sweet at first with tart apple following.  Lively carbonation on the tongue with a nice light lemon finish.  Pretty good stuff.

A nice cider.  Not as sweet as some, and it doesnt have the yeasty, barnyard character of some ciders, but still very good.  Champagne yeast in the aroma with apple.  Very heavily carbonated.  Medium sweet flavor, some marshmellow, and a dry finish.  Light and airy palate.

Tasted at Joes final Cellars tasting.  This is one of the best ciders I have ever had.  Nice golden pour with a small white head.  Several apple variations in the aroma with a small touch of honey.  Nice champagne mouth feel.  Taste is a nice mix of sweet and tart apple.

[Bottle, thanks for putting it in the lineup Joebrew] Pours golden with a good white head and lots of bubbles like champagne. Aroma and taste have the obvious apple, but there is also a good amount of oak. Medium-thin mouthfeel with the lively carbonation mentioned before. I would echo Joebrews statement that it is very nice, but maybe not worth the price.

This is very nice, almost like a nice demi-sec champagne.  Great carbonated mouthfeel with a nice light citrusy kick as well as some nice honey and tart green apple.  A very nice cider, but I dont know that I would pay $22-23 for it.
user_location: Farewell Minny; Hello Puyallup, Washington, USA

text: From Joebrews farewell Cellars tasting.  Gold color with a thin head.  Aroma of tart apples.  The initial apple hit is very sweet, but it quickly morphs into an almost bitter and tart finish.  A little oak is still noticeable.  Massive carbonation, very similar to Champagne.  Tasty fine.

750 ml bottle. Wonderfully rich aroma of semisweet, sweet and bitter apple must. Light notes of cut grass, new oak and sauvignon blanc. Pours a bright, bold gold with very tiny bubbles seeming to struggle to get to the surface leaving a sustained white ring around the flute. Tart, slightly acidic with only a bit of residual sugar sweetness. Again, new oak, plenty of apple must and dry apple skin. Ultra fine carbonation doesnt distract one bit. Finishes slightly bitter with a pleasant tart apple acidity.

Bottle (75 cl) from Systembolaget. Clear yellow with a fizzy and short white head. Aroma of fresh yellow and green apples with light notes of wood and butterscotch. Soft mouthfeel with a tender but lively carbonation. Refreshing acidity, a light sweetness, and a mild bitterness in a wonderful union. The relatively high alcohol content is nowhere to be found.

Thanx Boboski for sharing.Wow its like apple juice.It looks like apple juice and smells like apple juice but the taste blows apple juice away.lots of fresh apples and some wood in the flavor.The finish was clean, fresh and refreshing.

UPDATED: NOV 29, 2007 Bottle (2004)O-Town Throwdown Part Tres...  Clear, light yellow cider with a small, fizzy, white head. Smells of aged apples in high heat; the kind used to make apple butter. Also, notes of white wine, vanilla and wood. Apple-sweet flavor is balanced by heavy, mega tart acidity. Almost medium-bodied and ultra fizzy. Finishes sweet, and then acidic, astringent and Sahara-dry.

Thanks to Boboski for including me in this tasting. Pours very light like a apple sparkling wine. Dry apple and caramel aroma. Light apple taste, not sweet very smooth and refreshing. Finishes dry with a nice carbonation. Very very good.

Date: 11/17/2007
Mode: Bottle
Source: Tasting, Throwdown 3

clear dark yellow, frothy white head around the edges, 
dry fruit aroma with a crisp tart apple character with a light sweet winey character, 
lots of apple flavor, just a touch of sweetness followed by a nice sharp tartness, 

Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 15/20
Rating: 3.5/5.0Drinkability: 8/10
Score: **4

2004, released in 07, consumed fresh. Wow, wow, wow! I have enjoyed Louis Duponts creations for years, but this is an achievement I was not prepared to encounter. Completely crystalline, sparkling pour with a nearly negligible amount of visible, microscopic bubbles in near stasis that gradually glide to the top and keep a ring of white foam sustained at the edge of the glass. Were this poured into a proper flute, as evidenced in successive pours into other glasses, this would have generated and sustained a lovely foamy topper. The body is an extremely beautiful light gold; in fact, very rarely is this color a shade so beautiful or worthy of such verbose praise. Must escapes from the vessel first, followed quickly by easily separable multiple apple varieties, very clean and lively. Residual sugars are sparse but when encountered become dazzling and boisterous. Oak and vanilla are mild and candied/tar, yeast is nearly completely transparent. Alcohol is only very mildly detectable and is not bothersome. This has an absolutely fantastic nose! Clean and crisp but inundated and blanketed with cellaring effects that lay out like a panoramic photograph with tangibly explained intricacies. Short version: I feel the aroma. Complexity is midrange but several doses offer multiple alluring apple scents and easygoing earthy collaboration. The flavor is just as focused but remains so drinkable its nearly absurd. Apple has a constant of oak riding its tailwinds but never interfering with the fruit itself, or its intent of cleansing and refreshing the palate. Acidity is light to medium and only serves to sway astringency away from the most sensistive parts of the tongue. Sweetness swirls about and fades into a delicate, earthy and clean finish. The finale is one of awe-inspiring cleanness, huge but silky soft, with only a whisper of tartness and full diminishment of sugars leaving only light dryness and then oak and yeast, and then...nothing. Amazing. The mouthfeel is soft and light bodied that brushes with fuller moments. This is like a pure element(apple) being confronted with another angry dissident(earthy, cellar influence). Purity crushes the intruder with one swift blow. Wow, wow, wow!

Pours a crystal clear, light golden body.  Microscopic carbonation bubbles soar to the surface where they pool into a tiny, fizzy, white head.  The aroma shows a beautiful bouquet of tart green and sweet red apples. The flavor is the same.  This is not an overly complex cider, but its sugar levels are near perfect, lending to a wonderful balance between sweet and tart.  Incredibly fresh tasting.  Flavors are concentrated and bright.  The tasty finish is moderately dry.  Perfect carbonation. Incredibly drinkable.  This might be my Christmas morning drink of choice.  Awesome cider!

First rating for this beer!  Pours a lovely, bubbly, crystal clear gold, with a tiny bubbly head.  Huge apple aroma, alot of sweet citrus notes, and maybe a touch of some earthiness to it.  The apple really is the dominating smell though.  The flavor is really well balanced.  Carbonation seemed about right, and the apple flavor wasnt overdone like it can be in other ciders.  Big finish, not too dry, and really flavorful.  Pretty damn kick ass cider.  Pricey as hell, but really glad I got to try this one.
